Subclassing: Objective/Subjective [1/34]

Objective is applied to things exterior to the mind, and objects of its attention; subjective, to the operations of the mind itself. Hence, an objective motive is some outward thing awakening desire; a subjective motive is some internal feeling or propensity. Objective views are those governed by outward things; subjective views are produced or modified by internal feeling. Sir Walter Scott's poetry is chiefly objective; that of Wordsworth is eminently subjective. --- Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary (1913)

In the philosophy of mind, subjective denotes what is to be referred to the thinking subject, the ego; objective what belongs to the object of thought, the non-ego. --Sir. W. Hamilton

Normally we think of class interface as objective: What can we do to an instance?

The subjective interface is that visible to subclasses: What can an instance do to itself?

Subclassing: Designing for Subclassing [2/34]

java.util.Observable is designed to be subclassed.

The public interface: 

00001: public class Observable {
00002:   public Observable();
00003:   public void addObserver(Observer o);
00004:   public void deleteObserver(Observer o);
00005:   public void notifyObservers();
00006:   public void notifyObservers(Object arg);
00007:   public void deleteObservers();
00008:   public boolean hasChanged();
00009:   public int countObservers();
00010: }

The protected interface: 

00001: public class Observable {
00002:   ...
00003:   protected void setChanged();
00004:   protected void clearChanged();
00005: }

So to specify that the state is changed you have to be "inside" the observable...

The class is useless if you don't subclass it. 

00001: public class Counter extends Observable {
00002:   private int _i;
00003:   CounterObj() { _i=0; }
00004:   public void inc() {
00005:     _i++;
00006:     super.setChanged();      // could replace "super" with "this" or nothing
00007:     super.notifyObservers(); // could replace "super" with "this" or nothing
00008:   }
00009: }

Counter.deleteObservers() is public!

At the object level: 

   +-----------+
   | : Counter |
   | --------- |
   +-----------+

At the class level: 

   +------------+         +------------+
   | Counter    |- - - -|>| Observable |
   +------------+         +------------+

Subclassing: Designing for Delegation [3/34]

file:observableByDelegation/Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package observableByDelegation;
00002: 
00003: public class Main {
00004:   public static void main(String[] args) {
00005:     Counter c = new Counter();
00006:     c.addObserver(new Observer<Counter,Object>() {
00007:       public void update(Counter sender, Object data) {
00008:         System.out.println("update(" + sender + "," + data + ")");
00009:       }});
00010:     c.inc();
00011:     c.inc();
00012:     c.notifyObservers("Dog");
00013:     c.notifyObservers("Cat");
00014:     c.inc();
00015:     c.inc();
00016:     c.inc();
00017:     c.notifyObservers("Pig");
00018:   }
00019: }
00020: 
00021: class Counter {
00022:   ObservableHelper<Counter,Object> _oh = new ObservableHelper<Counter,Object>(this);
00023:   public void addObserver(Observer<Counter, Object> observer) {
00024:     _oh.addObserver(observer);
00025:   }
00026:   public void notifyObservers(Object data) {
00027:     _oh.notifyObservers(data);
00028:   }
00029: 
00030:   int _j;
00031:   public int get() {
00032:     return _j;
00033:   }
00034:   public void inc() {
00035:     _j++;
00036:     _oh.setChanged();
00037:   }
00038:   public String toString() {
00039:     return "Counter(" + _j + ")";
00040:   }
00041: }
00042:     
00043:

file:observableByDelegation/Observer.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package observableByDelegation;
00002: /**
00003:  * Author:  Matthew Stachowski
00004:  */
00005: 
00006: /**
00007:  * A generic observer which a class can implement when it wants to be informed
00008:  * of changes in observable objects.
00009:  * 
00010:  * @param <T>
00011:  *            the type of object being observed
00012:  * @param <U>
00013:  *            the type of the optinal data argument
00014:  * 
00015:  * @see ObservableHelper
00016:  */
00017: public interface Observer<T, U> {
00018:   /**
00019:    * This method is called whenever the observed object is changed.
00020:    * 
00021:    * @param sender
00022:    *            the object which was the source of the notification.
00023:    * @param data
00024:    *            an optional data parameter which encapsulates any additional
00025:    *            data about the event
00026:    */
00027:   void update(T sender, U data);
00028: }

file:observableByDelegation/ObservableHelper.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package observableByDelegation;
00002: /**
00003:  * Author:  Matthew Stachowski
00004:  */
00005: 
00006: import java.util.ArrayList;
00007: import java.util.List;
00008: 
00009: /**
00010:  * A helper class which can be used to manage an object's observers.
00011:  * 
00012:  * @param <T>
00013:  *            the type of object being observed
00014:  * @param <U>
00015:  *            the type of the optional data argument
00016:  * 
00017:  * @see Observer
00018:  */
00019: public final class ObservableHelper<T, U> {
00020:   private final T observed;
00021:   private final List<Observer<T, U>> observers;
00022:   private boolean changed = false;
00023:   
00024:   /**
00025:    * Initializes a new instance of the {@link ObservableHelper} class with
00026:    * zero observers.
00027:    * 
00028:    * @param observed
00029:    *            the object being observed
00030:    * @throws IllegalArgumentException
00031:    *             if observed is <code>null</code>
00032:    */
00033:   public ObservableHelper(T observed) {
00034:     if (observed == null)
00035:       throw new IllegalArgumentException("observed cannot be null");
00036:     this.observed = observed;
00037:     this.observers = new ArrayList<Observer<T, U>>();
00038:   }
00039:   
00040:   /**
00041:    * Adds an observer to the set of observers for the observed object,
00042:    * provided that it is not the same as some observer already in the set.
00043:    * 
00044:    * @param observer
00045:    * @throws IllegalArgumentException
00046:    *             if the parameter observer is <code>null</code>
00047:    */
00048:   public void addObserver(Observer<T, U> observer) {
00049:     if (observer == null)
00050:       throw new IllegalArgumentException("observer cannot be null");
00051:     if (!observers.contains(observer)) {
00052:       observers.add(observer);
00053:     }
00054:   }
00055:   
00056:   /**
00057:    * Indicates that the observed object has no longer changed, or that it has
00058:    * already notified all of its observers of its most recent change, so that
00059:    * {@link #hasChanged()} will now return <code>false</code>. This method
00060:    * is called automatically by the {@link #notifyObservers} methods.
00061:    * 
00062:    */
00063:   public void clearChanged() {
00064:     changed = false;
00065:   }
00066:   
00067:   /**
00068:    * Returns the number of observers of observed object.
00069:    * 
00070:    * @return the number of observers of observed object
00071:    */
00072:   public int countObservers() {
00073:     return observers.size();
00074:   }
00075:   
00076:   /**
00077:    * Deletes an observer from the set of observers. Passing <code>null</code>
00078:    * to this method will have no effect.
00079:    * 
00080:    * @param observer
00081:    *            the {@link Observer} to be deleted
00082:    */
00083:   public void deleteObserver(Observer<T, U> observer) {
00084:     observers.remove(observer);
00085:   }
00086:   
00087:   /**
00088:    * Clears the observer list so that the observed object no longer has any
00089:    * observers.
00090:    */
00091:   public void deleteObservers() {
00092:     this.observers.clear();
00093:   }
00094:   
00095:   /**
00096:    * Returns <code>true</code> if the observed object has changed;
00097:    * otherwise, <code>false</code>.
00098:    * 
00099:    * @return <code>true</code> if the observed object has changed;
00100:    *         otherwise, <code>false</code>
00101:    */
00102:   public boolean hasChanged() {
00103:     return changed;
00104:   }
00105:   
00106:   /**
00107:    * If this object has changed, as indicated by the {@link #hasChanged()},
00108:    * then notify all of its observers and then clear the changed state. This
00109:    * method is equivalent to calling <code>notifyObservers(null)</code>.
00110:    */
00111:   public void notifyObservers() {
00112:     notifyObservers(null);
00113:   }
00114:   
00115:   /**
00116:    * If this object has changed, as indicated by the {@link #hasChanged()},
00117:    * then notify all of its observers and then clear the changed state.
00118:    * 
00119:    * @param data
00120:    *            optional event specific data which will be passed to the
00121:    *            observers
00122:    */
00123:   public void notifyObservers(U data) {
00124:     if (hasChanged()) {
00125:       for (Observer<T, U> observer : observers) {
00126:         observer.update(observed, data);
00127:       }
00128:       clearChanged();
00129:     }
00130:   }
00131:   
00132:   /**
00133:    * Flags the observed object as having changed.
00134:    */
00135:   public void setChanged() {
00136:     changed = true;
00137:   }
00138: }

Disadvantage of subclassing in Java: must export interface of superclass.

Advantage of subclassing in Java: syntactically light, easy to share fields.

Subclassing: Delgation versus Subclassing [4/34]

Read the following diagram as ``every instance of Counter has a reference to an instance of ObservableHelper.'' 

   +------------+       1 +------------------+
   | Counter    |<>-----> | ObservableHelper |
   +------------+         +------------------+

Subclassing defines a single object incrementally.
In JAVA, says that subclass interface extends superclass interface.

Read the following diagram as ``every instance of Counter is also an instance of Observable.'' 

   +------------+         +------------+
   | Counter    |- - - -|>| Observable |
   +------------+         +------------+

At run time, objects have references to the objects they know about. This is the object graph or heap.

At compile time, classes are related via subclassing and subtyping (as well as other dependencies). This is the class hierarchy.

Subclassing: Abstract classes [5/34]

Often an intended superclass will be abstract.

An abstract class cannot be instantiated. It may have abstract methods.

java.util.Observable should be abstract, since it is useless unless subclassed. (Alternatively setChanged() and clearChanged() should be public.)

java.awt.Component is abstract.

Subclassing: Final classes [6/34]

A final class cannot be subclassed.

An final class may not have abstract methods.

java.lang.String is final.

Subclassing: How to choose? [7/34]

General rule (GoF): prefer delegation.

Main reason: choices can be delayed. Subclassing is fixed at compile time. Delegation can be determined (and changed) at runtime.

Delegation can be difficult when methods are interdependent.

Overriding: Code Inheritance [8/34]

A subclass can inherit code from its superclass. 

00001: class B {
00002:   void f() { ... }
00003: }
00004: class D extends B {
00005:   void g() { ... }
00006: }
00007: class Main {
00008:   public static void main(String[] args) {
00009:     D x = new D();
00010:     x.g();  // executing code from D
00011:     x.f();  // executing inherited code from B
00012:   }
00013: }

Overriding: Hiding [9/34]

A declaration is hidden if another declaration of the same name occurs in the scope of the outer declaration. 

00001: public class A {
00002:     int x;
00003:     static void z() { ... }
00004: }
00005: public class B extends A {
00006:     float x;                // old x still in scope, use super.x
00007:     static int z() { ... }  // old z still in scope, use A.z()
00008:     byte x (char x) {       // oh dear...
00009:       char c = x;
00010:       float f = this.x;
00011:       int i = super.x;
00012:       byte b = this.x();
00013:     }
00014: }

You should avoid hiding

http://developer.java.sun.com/developer/TechTips/2000/tt1010.html#tip2

Overriding: Overriding [10/34]

Overriding: a non-static method in a subclass has the same name and signature as a non-static method in the superclass.

Intuition: the method implementation in the subclass ``replaces'' the implementation of the method in the superclass.

Example:

00001: class B {
00002:   public void m() { ... }
00003: }
00004: class D extends B {
00005:   public void m() { ... }
00006: }
00007: B b = new B(); b.m(); // invoke m in class B
00008: D d = new D(); d.m(); // invoke m in class D

Overriding: Overloading [11/34]

To override a method, the argument types must be the same in super and subclass.

If the types are different, the result is overloading not overriding.

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package subclass.overload;
00002: 
00003: class A {
00004:   public void m(String s) { System.out.println("A"); }
00005: }
00006: class B extends A { 
00007:   public void m(Object o) { System.out.println("B"); }
00008: }
00009: 
00010: class Main {
00011:   private void Main() {}
00012:   public static void main(String[] args) {
00013:     String y = "?";
00014:     Object x = y;
00015:     B b = new B();
00016:     A a = b;
00017:     a.m(y);
00018:     // a.m(x);
00019:     b.m(y);
00020:     b.m(x);
00021:   }
00022: }

Overriding: Method Dispatch (aka Method Resolution) [12/34]

When an overridden method is invoked, we have to decide which implementation to run. There are two ways to do this: based on the static or dynamic type.

Recall

static refers to properties of the text of a program (synonyms are lexical, compile-time and early).

dynamic refers to properties of an execution of a program (synonyms are run-time and late).

declared type = compile-time type.
actual type = run-time type.

Both forms of method resolution proceed up the class hierarchy, using the superclass relation. In pseudo-code: 

lookup(C,m)
  // return the address of code for method m
  if (C implements m) then
    return address of C.m
  else
    let B = the superclass of C
    return lookup(B,m)

Procedurally: if m is implemented in C then return the address of C.m else set C to be the superclass of C and repeat.

Static dispatch (early binding): start lookup with the declared type.

Dynamic dispatch (late binding): start lookup with the actual type.

Overriding: Instance methods [13/34]

Instance methods [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package subclass;
00002: 
00003: // Instance methods
00004: public class M1 {
00005:   public static void main(String[] argv) {
00006:     (new B1()).m();
00007:   }
00008: }
00009: class A1 {
00010:   void m() {
00011:     System.out.println("A.m");
00012:     this.p(); // static or dynamic binding?
00013:   }
00014:   void p() {System.out.println("A.p");}
00015: }
00016: class B1 extends A1 {
00017:   void p() {System.out.println("B.p");}
00018: }

00010:   void m() {
00011:     System.out.println("A.m");
00012:     this.p(); // static or dynamic binding?
00013:   }
00014:   static void p() {System.out.println("A.p");}
00015: }
00016: class B2 extends A2 {
00017:   static void p() {System.out.println("B.p");}
00018: }

Overriding: super and this [15/34]

super and this [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package subclass;
00002: 
00003: // Super
00004: public class M3 {
00005:   public static void main(String[] argv) {
00006:     (new C3()).m();
00007:   }
00008: }
00009: class A3 {
00010:   void m() {System.out.println("A.m");}
00011:   void p() {System.out.println("A.p");}
00012: }
00013: class B3 extends A3 {
00014:   void p() {
00015:     System.out.println("B.m");
00016:     this.p();  // static or dynamic binding?
00017:     super.p(); // static or dynamic binding?
00018:   }
00019: 
00020:   void m() {
00021:     System.out.println("B.m");
00022:   }
00023: }
00024: class C3 extends B3 {
00025:   void p() {System.out.println("C.p");}
00026: }

00011:     System.out.println("A.m");

00013:   }
00014:   private void p() {System.out.println("A.p");}

00018: }

Overriding: Inner Classes [17/34]

Dynamic or static? [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package subclass;
00002: public class M9 {
00003:   public static void main(String[] argv) {
00004:     O o = new X();
00005:     I i = o.getI();
00006:     i.m();
00007:   }
00008: }
00009: interface I { public void m(); }
00010: class O {
00011:   I getI() { return new I() {
00012:       public void m() {
00013:         O.this.p(); // static or dynamic binding?
00014:       }};
00015:   }
00016:   void p() { System.out.println("O.p"); }
00017: }
00018: class X extends O {
00019:   void p() {System.out.println("X.p");}
00020: }

Overriding: Class fields [18/34]

Class fields [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package subclass;
00002: 
00003: // Class Fields
00004: public class M5 {
00005:   public static void main(String[] argv) {
00006:     (new B5()).p();
00007:   }
00008: }
00009: class A5 {
00010:   static void m() {
00011:     System.out.println("A.m: " + _x); // which _x?
00012:   }
00013:   static final int _x = 42;
00014: }
00015: class B5 extends A5 {
00016:   void p() {
00017:     this.m();
00018:     System.out.println("B.p: " + _x); // which _x?
00019:   }
00020:   static final int _x = 27;
00021: }

00002: 
00003: // Instance Fields
00004: public class M6 {
00005:   public static void main(String[] argv) {
00006:     (new B6()).p();
00007:   }
00008: }
00009: class A6 {
00010:   void m() {
00011:     System.out.println("A.m: " + _x); // which _x?
00012:   }
00013:   final int _x = 42;
00014: }
00015: class B6 extends A6 {
00016:   void p() {
00017:     this.m();
00018:     System.out.println("B.p: " + _x); // which _x?
00019:   }
00020:   final int _x = 27;
00021: }

Overriding: C++/C# [20/34]

C++ and C# default to static dispatch, for all functions, including member functions.

To get dynamic dispatch, use the keyword virtual.

C# structs may not include virtual members.

In C#, an instance of a class is always boxed, and messages are dynamically dispatched; an instance of a struct is unboxed, and messages are statically dispatched.

In C++, objects of any class my be boxed or unboxed. For example: 

00001: string* sp = new string("dog"); // boxed
00002: string  s  = string("cat");     // unboxed

If you are interested in C#, see here: http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en-us/csspec/html/vclrfcsharpspec_11_3.asp

Method dispatch in C++ is complicated. See file:dynamicVersusStaticDispatch.cpp [source].

Overriding: Equals [21/34]

Equals in a final class (non-extendable concrete class). Return true if for each field _f: this._f.equals(that._f) 

00001: final public class C {
00002:   public boolean equals(Object thatObject) {
00003:     if (!(thatObject instanceof C))
00004:       return false;
00005:     C that = (C) thatObject;
00006:     return ...;
00007: } }

Equals in an extendable concrete class. 

00001: public class C {
00002:   public boolean equals(Object thatObject) {
00003:     if ((thatObject == null) || (thatObject.getClass() != this.getClass()))
00004:       return false;
00005:     C that = (C) thatObject;
00006:     return ...;
00007: } }

CompareTo sanity: (x.compareTo(y)<0 implies y.compareTo(x)>0) 

00001: final public class C {
00002:   public int compareTo(Object thatObject) {
00003:     C that = (C) thatObject;
00004:     return ...;
00005: } }
00006: public class C {
00007:   public int compareTo(Object thatObject) {
00008:     if ((thatObject == null) || (thatObject.getClass() != this.getClass()))
00009:       throw new ClassCastException();
00010:     C that = (C) thatObject;
00011:     return ...;
00012: } }

An example of the problem.

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package subclass.equals;
00002: class C1 {
00003:   int _i;
00004:   public C1(int i) { _i = i; }
00005:   public boolean equals(Object thatObject) {
00006:     if (!(thatObject instanceof C1))
00007:       return false;
00008:     C1 that = (C1) thatObject;
00009:     return that._i == this._i;
00010:   }
00011: }
00012: class D1 extends C1 {
00013:   int _j;
00014:   public D1(int i, int j) { super(i); _j = j; }
00015:   public boolean equals(Object thatObject) {
00016:     if (!(thatObject instanceof D1))
00017:       return false;
00018:     D1 that = (D1) thatObject;
00019:     return that._i == this._i && that._j == this._j;
00020:   }
00021: }
00022: class C2 {
00023:   int _i;
00024:   public C2(int i) { _i = i; }
00025:   public boolean equals(Object thatObject) {
00026:     if ((thatObject == null) || (thatObject.getClass() != this.getClass()))
00027:       return false;
00028:     C2 that = (C2) thatObject;
00029:     return that._i == this._i;
00030:   }
00031: }
00032: class D2 extends C2{
00033:   int _j;
00034:   public D2(int i, int j) { super(i); _j = j; }
00035:   public boolean equals(Object thatObject) {
00036:     if ((thatObject == null) || (thatObject.getClass() != this.getClass()))
00037:       return false;
00038:     D2 that = (D2) thatObject;
00039:     return that._i == this._i && that._j == this._j;
00040:   }
00041: }
00042: public class Main {
00043:   public static void main(String[] args) {
00044:     C1 x1 = new C1(27);
00045:     C1 y1 = new D1(27,42);
00046:     System.out.println("x1==y1? " + (x1.equals(y1) ? "true" : "false"));
00047:     System.out.println("y1==x1? " + (y1.equals(x1) ? "true" : "false"));
00048: 
00049:     C2 x2 = new C2(27);
00050:     C2 y2 = new D2(27,42);
00051:     System.out.println("x2==y2? " + (x2.equals(y2) ? "true" : "false"));
00052:     System.out.println("y2==x2? " + (y2.equals(x2) ? "true" : "false"));
00053:   }
00054: }

Template Method: Some code [22/34] 

00001: interface Series {
00002:   void next();
00003:   void print();
00004: }
00005: class Arithmetic implements Series {
00006:   public void next()  {  _y += 2;  _x++ }
00007:   public void print() { System.out.println("x=" + _x + ";y=" + _y); }
00008:   int _y = 1;
00009:   int _x;
00010: }
00011: class Geometric implements Series {
00012:   public void next()  {  _y *= 2;  _x++ }
00013:   public void print() { System.out.println("x=" + _x + ";y=" + _y); }
00014:   int _y = 1;
00015:   int _x;
00016: }

Template Method: Using Delegation (Strategy) [23/34] 

00001: class ConcreteSeries implements Series {
00002:     ConcreteSeries(GetNext g) { _g = g; }
00003:     public void next()  {  _y = _g.getNext(_y);  _x++; }
00004:     public void print() { System.out.println("x=" + _x + ";y=" + _y); }
00005:     GetNext _g;
00006:     int _y = 1;
00007:     int _x;
00008: }
00009: interface GetNext {
00010:     int getNext(int y);
00011: }
00012: class Arithmetic implements GetNext {
00013:     public int getNext(int y) { return y + 2; }
00014: }
00015: class Geometric implements GetNext {
00016:     public int getNext(int y) { return y * 2; }
00017: }

Template Method: The Strategy Pattern [24/34]

Describe a function in two parts: the part that varies goes in a separate class.

Non-software example: file:links-main

Here is a class diagram from the GOF:

Template Method: Using Subclassing (Template) [25/34] 

00001: abstract class AbstractSeries implements Series {
00002:     abstract public int getNext(int y);
00003:     public void next()  {  _y = getNext(_y);  _x++; }
00004:     public void print() { System.out.println("x=" + _x + ";y=" + _y); }
00005:     int _y = 1;
00006:     int _x;
00007: }
00008: class Arithmetic extends AbstractSeries {
00009:     public int getNext(int y) { return y + 2; }
00010: }
00011: class Geometric extends AbstractSeries {
00012:     public int getNext(int y) { return y * 2; }
00013: }

Template Method: The Template Method Pattern [26/34]

Describe a function in two parts: the part that varies goes in a subclass.

Non-software example: file:links-main

Here is a class diagram from the GOF:

Template Method: Template Method is NOT inheritance [27/34]

Inheritance: 

00001: class B {
00002:   void f() { ... }
00003: }
00004: class D extends B {
00005:   void g() { ... f() ... }
00006: }

Template Method: 

00001: class B {
00002:   void f() { ... g() ... }
00003:   abstract void g();
00004: }
00005: class D extends B {
00006:   void g() { ... }
00007: }

Template Method: Hook Methods [28/34]

Abstract method (mandatory hook method)

  • Must be overridden.

Hook method

  • Intended to be overridden.

Concrete method

  • Not intended to be overridden (but might be).

Final method

  • May not be overridden.

Template Method: A Heirarchy of Abstraction [29/34]

interface (aka, pure abstract class)

  • No method bodies, No instance fields
  • May not be instantiated
  • Must be implemented to be useful

abstract class

  • Optional method bodies
  • May not be instantiated
  • Must be extended to be useful (except class methods)

concrete non-final class

  • Required method bodies
  • May be instantiated
  • May be extended

final class

  • Required method bodies
  • May be instantiated
  • May not be extended

Advice: Make concrete classes final unless they are specifically designed to be subclassed.

Template Method: Interfaces and Abstract classes [30/34]

Guideline: Always provide an interface. If you want to provide implementation for subtypes, you can additionally provide an abstract class: 

00001: package x;
00002: public interface I {
00003:   void m();
00004:   void n();
00005: }
00006: public class IAbstract {
00007:   abstract public void m();
00008:   public void n() { ... }    // provide an implementation of n
00009:   protected void f() { ... } // provide an implementation of f
00010: }
00011: 
00012: package y;
00013: public class IObj extends x.IAbstract {
00014:   public void m() { ...  f() ... }  // use IAbstract's implementation of f
00015: }
00016: 
00017: package main;
00018: public class Main {
00019:   public static void main(String[] args) {
00020:     x.I a = new y.IObj();
00021:     a.m();
00022:     a.n();
00023:   }
00024: }

Template Method: Template Example [31/34]

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package template.ftoc;
00002: import java.io.BufferedReader;
00003: import java.io.InputStreamReader;
00004: import java.io.IOException;
00005: 
00006: /* This example is from Robert C. Martin */
00007: public class Main {
00008:   public static void main(String[] args) {
00009:     (new FtoC()).run();
00010:   }
00011: }
00012: /* public */
00013: abstract class Application {
00014:   private boolean _isDone = false;
00015:   
00016:   protected abstract void init();
00017:   protected abstract void idle();
00018:   protected abstract void cleanup();
00019:   protected boolean done() {
00020:     return _isDone;
00021:   }
00022:   protected void setDone() {
00023:     _isDone = true;
00024:   }
00025:   public void run() {
00026:     init();
00027:     while (!done())
00028:       idle();
00029:     cleanup();
00030:   }
00031: }
00032: final class FtoC extends Application {
00033:   private BufferedReader _br;
00034:   
00035:   protected void init() {
00036:     _br = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
00037:   }
00038:   protected void idle() {
00039:     String fstring = readLine();
00040:     if (fstring == null || fstring.length() == 0) {
00041:       setDone();
00042:     } else {
00043:       double f = Double.parseDouble(fstring);
00044:       double c = 5.0/9.0*(f-32);
00045:       System.out.println("F=" + f + ", C=" + c);
00046:     }
00047:   }
00048:   protected void cleanup() {
00049:     System.out.println("FtoC exit");
00050:   }
00051:   private String readLine() {
00052:     try { return _br.readLine(); }
00053:     catch(IOException e) { return null; }
00054:   }
00055: }

Template Method: Refactor to Strategy [32/34]

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package strategy.ftoc;
00002: import java.io.BufferedReader;
00003: import java.io.InputStreamReader;
00004: import java.io.IOException;
00005: 
00006: /* This example is from Robert C. Martin */
00007: public class Main {
00008:   public static void main(String[] args) {
00009:     (new App(new FtoC())).run();
00010:   }
00011: }
00012: final class App {
00013:   private AppStrategy _s;
00014:   public App(AppStrategy s) {
00015:     _s = s;
00016:   }
00017:   public void run() {
00018:     _s.init();
00019:     while (!_s.done())
00020:       _s.idle();
00021:     _s.cleanup();
00022:   }
00023: }
00024: /* public */
00025: interface AppStrategy {
00026:   public void init();
00027:   public void idle();
00028:   public void cleanup();
00029:   public boolean done();
00030: }
00031: final class FtoC implements AppStrategy {
00032:   private boolean _isDone = false;
00033:   private BufferedReader _br;
00034: 
00035:   public boolean done() {
00036:     return _isDone;
00037:   }
00038:   public void init() {
00039:     _br = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
00040:   }
00041:   public void idle() {
00042:     String fstring = readLine();
00043:     if (fstring == null || fstring.length() == 0) {
00044:       _isDone = true;
00045:     } else {
00046:       double f = Double.parseDouble(fstring);
00047:       double c = 5.0/9.0*(f-32);
00048:       System.out.println("F=" + f + ", C=" + c);
00049:     }
00050:   }
00051:   public void cleanup() {
00052:     System.out.println("FtoC exit");
00053:   }
00054:   private String readLine() {
00055:     try { return _br.readLine(); }
00056:     catch(IOException e) { return null; }
00057:   }
00058: }

Choosing Delegation [33/34]

GoF: prefer delegation. Subclassing is too static -- forces awkward class hierachies -- inflexible. 

         /------------\
         | Deal       |
         \------------/
           /_\    /_\  
            |      |   
                       
            |      |   
 +------------+  +-------------+
 | ActiveDeal |  | PassiveDeal |
 +------------+  +-------------+
     /_\              /_\
      |                |
      |                |
 +------------+  +-------------+
 | Tabular    |  | Tabular     |
 | ActiveDeal |  | PassiveDeal |
 +------------+  +-------------+

versus 

         /------------\                  1 /-------------------\
         | Deal       |<>----------------> | PresentationStyle |
         \------------/                    \-------------------/
           /_\    /_\                          /_\    /_\           
            |      |                            |      |            
                                                                    
            |      |                            |      |            
 +------------+  +-------------+     +------------+  +-------------+
 | ActiveDeal |  | PassiveDeal |     | TabularPS  |  | SinglePS    |
 +------------+  +-------------+     +------------+  +-------------+

In english, we often say "is" when we mean "has the attribute of".

"The shirt is purple" versus "The shirt has a color attribute, which is purple".

"The room is a cuboid" versus "The room has a shape attribute, which is cuboid".

Choosing Subclassing [34/34]

GoF: When a subclass overrides some but not all operations, it can affect the operations it inherits as well, assuming they call the overridden operations.

Delegation is difficult to code when strategies are interdependent.

For an example see Painting in AWT and Swing.

paint and update are related hook methods.

repaint is a non-final template method, which (indirectly) calls update. 

00001: public abstract class Component ... { ...
00002:   public void paint(Graphics g) {  } // Used for system-triggered painting
00003:   public void update(Graphics g) {   // Used for application-triggered painting
00004:     paint(g); // default implementation
00005:   }
00006:   public void repaint() {
00007:     // requests that the GUI thread call back to "update" at some point
00008:   }
00009: }

By default, overriding paint affects repaint and update.

repaint and update can also be independently overridden.

In my opinion, paint should be abstract.

Revised: 2007/11/01 17:36
